section.title: Imaginary situations in the past with if
section.sectiontitle: We use If + Past perfect to describe an imaginary situation in the past. We use would/could/might + have + past participle to describe an imaginary result in the past. This is often called the 'Third conditional'.
section.text1: He didn't stay at home and as a result, he met his wife.
section.text1a: If he'd stayed at home that day, he wouldn't have met his wife.
section.text2: I spent all my money and as a result, I didn't buy a new car.
section.text2a: If I hadn't spent all my money I could have bought a new car.
section.sectiontitle2: If the result is in the present, we use would/could/might be in the result clause.
section.text3: She didn't stay in her job and she isn't rich now.
section.text3a: If she'd stayed in her job, she would be rich now.
section.text4: I moved to Switzerland and we're now married.
section.text4a: If I hadn't moved to Switzerland we might not be married now.
